newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Canberra sees growth, jobs under new labour system.
newsitem.headline: Canberra sees growth, jobs under new labour system.

text.p: Australia's conservative government promised more jobs and faster economic growth on Monday after securing essential minor-party backing for radical labour relations reforms.

Industrial Relations Minister Peter Reith, who concluded a weekend deal to get his reforms through parliament, said the system inherited from the former Labor government was too rigid and discouraged flexible wage contracts to boost productivity.
"We're addressing those problems," Reith told Reuters Financial Television.
"We're simplifying the system and all of that should encourage higher growth and of course from higher growth comes a better job outlook for the Australian community."

Like many Western economies, Australia suffers from intractably rising unemployment, even though it enjoys economic growth that averages more than three percent a year -- higher than most developed countries.
Although the unemployment rate has declined from a peak of 11 percent in 1992, it stopped falling at above eight percent a year ago and has now nudged up to 8.7 percent.

The government's answer has been to drive the economy faster -- Treasurer Peter Costello said this month that more than four percent growth was needed -- but it has arged that a well-oiled labour-relations system would produce greater productivity and non-inflationary growth.
Reith's deal with the Democrats at the weekend means his Workplace Relations Bill can pass through the upper house or Senate, where the government lacks a clear majority.
The Democrats will table 171 agreed amendments to the bill, although Reith said its "basic integrity" had been kept.
Trades unionists said the new laws, which would allow non-unionised workers to bypass them in making deals directly with employers, would only cause more strikes.
Traditionally, Australian wages were set by a central industrial court that heard arguments from unions and employers.
The Labor government, which lost power in March to a conservative coalition, had begun to deregulate the system but unions still kept their powerful role.

"I think industrial disputation will increase, particularly against companies that want to use the legislation for their own ideological purposes," the president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Jennie George, told reporters.
But Reith told Reuters he thought the the new system's cooperative approach would create industrial harmony.
"The changes to the agreement process will encourage a more cooperative, harmonious approach to workplace negotiations," he said.
Reith's bill is expected to become law within a few weeks and be put into operation as early as February next year.
